related_questions.question: How do you determine if you are diabetic?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Fasting Blood Sugar Test: This test measures your blood sugar level after an overnight fast (no food or drink except water for 8-12 hours).  Normal: Less than 100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L)  Prediabetes: 100 to 125 mg/dL (5.6 to 6.9 mmol/L)  Diabetes: 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher on two separate tests
Normal: Less than 100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L)
Prediabetes: 100 to 125 mg/dL (5.6 to 6.9 mmol/L)
Diabetes: 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher on two separate tests
Random Blood Sugar Test: This test can be done at any time, regardless of when you last ate.  A result of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher suggests diabetes, especially if accompanied by symptoms.
A result of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher suggests diabetes, especially if accompanied by symptoms.

A1C Test: This test provides an average of your blood sugar levels over the past 2-3 months.  You don't need to fast for this test.  Normal: Less than 5.7%  Prediabetes: 5.7% to 6.4%  Diabetes: 6.5% or higher
You don't need to fast for this test.
Normal: Less than 5.7%
Prediabetes: 5.7% to 6.4%
Diabetes: 6.5% or higher

Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT): This test is often used for pregnant women and those with cystic fibrosis. It involves drinking a sugary liquid and having your blood sugar tested at intervals.  Normal: Less than 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) after two hours  Prediabetes: 140 to 199 mg/dL (7.8 to 11.0 mmol/L) after two hours  Diabetes: 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher after two hours
Normal: Less than 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) after two hours
Prediabetes: 140 to 199 mg/dL (7.8 to 11.0 mmol/L) after two hours
Diabetes: 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher after two hours
Increased thirst and dry mouth
Frequent urination
Unexplained weight loss
Increased hunger
Blurred vision
Slow-healing sores or cuts
Fatigue
Frequent infections
Consult your doctor: If you experience any of the symptoms of diabetes, or if you are concerned about your risk, schedule an appointment with your doctor for testing.
Routine screenings: The American Diabetes Association recommends that all adults aged 35 and older have routine diabetes screenings.
Early detection is key: Early diagnosis and treatment can help prevent or delay the serious complications of diabetes.

related_questions.question: What are 10 warning signs of diabetes?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: 1.  Frequent urination: . Opens in new tabThis is often one of the earliest signs, as the body tries to flush out excess sugar through urine.
2.  Increased thirst: . Opens in new tabYou might feel unusually thirsty, even after drinking fluids, due to the body's attempt to compensate for fluid loss from frequent urination.
3.  Extreme hunger: . Opens in new tabDespite eating, you may still feel hungry because your body isn't properly converting food into energy.
4.  Fatigue: . Opens in new tabFeeling unusually tired or weak, even after getting enough sleep, can be a sign of diabetes.
5.  Blurry vision: . Opens in new tabHigh blood sugar can affect the lens of the eye, leading to temporary blurry vision.
6.  Slow-healing sores or cuts: . Opens in new tabDiabetes can impair the body's ability to heal, leading to wounds taking longer to close.
7.  Tingling or numbness in hands and feet: . Opens in new tabNerve damage (neuropathy) due to high blood sugar can cause these sensations.
8.  Frequent infections: . Opens in new tabPeople with diabetes are more susceptible to infections, especially yeast infections (both urinary and vaginal).
9.  Unexplained weight loss: . Opens in new tabIn some cases, particularly with type 1 diabetes, unexplained weight loss can occur despite increased appetite.
10.  Darkened skin patches: . Opens in new tabAcanthosis nigricans, a condition causing dark, velvety patches of skin, can be a sign of insulin resistance, a precursor to diabetes.

related_questions.question: What are the big 3 signs of diabetes?
related_questions.snippet: The three Ps are the most common signs of diabetes. Polyuria means frequent urination, polydipsia means excessive thirst, and polyphagia means excessive hunger.
related_questions.title: The Three Ps of Diabetes - Alabama Cooperative Extension System -

related_questions.question: How is diabetes diagnosed?
related_questions.snippet: Your doctor can diagnose diabetes, prediabetes, and gestational diabetes using blood tests. The blood tests show if your blood glucose level, also called blood sugar, is higher than the range that is healthy for you. Blood tests can also help identify the type of diabetes you have.
